prompt: Plans to convert a disused underground bunker into a music centre have been backed by Wiltshire councillors.
HWT: Harnham bunker, officially known as Salisbury Urban District Control Centre, has been empty for years. Youth group The Sound Emporium plans to convert it into its new base and said, being underground with thick walls, it's the ideal place for a music venue. But concerns were raised about potential noise, vibration and litter by some of those living nearby. Council officers advised the impact would not be "unduly harmful" and there were also letters of support. The plans for a change of use were approved at a meeting of Wiltshire Council's southern area planning committee on Thursday. Ross Sanderson, of the Sound Emporium, told the BBC the venue was "unique" and "inspiring". "What better place to have a music venue than underground, with the natural soundproofing of the earth plus between 5ft-10ft thick concrete walls?" Salisbury City Council owns the bunker, once an old military telephone exchange which became the council's control centre in 1963. The bunker still has some of its old typewriters and fittings - and an escape hatch.
MGT:
Wiltshire councillors have expressed support for an ambitious plan to transform a disused underground bunker into a vibrant music centre. The proposal, which has gained traction in recent weeks, aims to breathe new life into the abandoned site by turning it into a creative hub for musicians and artists.

The bunker, originally built during the Cold War era, has remained unused for decades. Advocates for the project believe its unique design and acoustics make it an ideal location for a state-of-the-art music centre. The facility is expected to include recording studios, rehearsal spaces, and performance areas, offering local musicians and bands a much-needed venue to hone their craft.

Residents and community groups have largely welcomed the initiative, citing its potential to boost the local economy and invigorate Wiltshire’s cultural scene. Supporters also emphasize the importance of repurposing abandoned structures to preserve historical significance while serving modern needs.

Councillors praised the innovative vision behind the plan and highlighted its alignment with the region’s goals of fostering arts and culture. While funding and logistical details are still under discussion, the project has taken a significant step forward with the council’s endorsement. If realized, the music centre could become a cornerstone of Wiltshire’s creative community.

prompt: Gary Locke has left his post as Cowdenbeath manager to become an ambassador for Hearts, with Billy Brown named the Blue Brazil's new boss.
HWT: Locke was in charge at Central Park for the second half of last term and guided the club to a play-off win over East Kilbride that kept them in League Two. Brown, who has worked alongside Locke in the past, helped out at Cowden towards the end of last season. The club say their aim remains to secure promotion next season. Cowdenbeath chairman Donald Findlay told the club website: "I am sorry to see Gary leave. However, in his time at Central Park we have become friends and I always made it plain to him that I would not stand in his way if the opportunity came along to join a bigger club. "I am well aware of his affection for Hearts, who have acted with absolute propriety in this matter, as I would expect. I will always be grateful for what he and Billy Brown did for the club at the end of the season and I have every confidence that Billy will carry on the good work." Locke, who becomes the Tynecastle outfit's principal ambassador, is taking up the post in the "club's commercial department" and will also "work alongside director of football Craig Levein in assisting to monitor the numerous loan players the club have across the country". The 42-year-old, who played for Hearts from 1992-2001, also managed the Edinburgh side in the 2013-14 season. Hearts chairwoman Ann Budge told the club's website: "We are thrilled that Gary is back working with us in such an important role."
MGT:
Gary Locke has stepped down from his role as manager of Cowdenbeath to embark on a new journey as an ambassador for Heart of Midlothian. Locke, who has been at the helm of Cowdenbeath, affectionately known as the Blue Brazil, has decided to make this career transition to rejoin Hearts, a club where he holds a significant legacy.

During his tenure with Cowdenbeath, Locke was admired for his dedication and leadership. His departure marks the end of a chapter for the club, but it also opens a new opportunity for him to foster relationships and promote the values of Heart of Midlothian in his ambassadorial role. This new position is seen as a strategic move by Hearts to strengthen their community ties and enhance their brand presence, with Locke’s deep-rooted connection to the club playing a pivotal role.

Following Locke's departure, Cowdenbeath acted swiftly to appoint Billy Brown as the new manager. Brown, who brings a wealth of experience and knowledge to the team, is no stranger to the pressures of Scottish football. With a reputation for nurturing talent and a keen tactical mind, Brown’s appointment has been well-received, with fans and players alike eager to see how his leadership will shape the future of the club.

Brown’s immediate focus will be on stabilizing the team's performance and instilling a fresh sense of purpose and ambition. As Cowdenbeath looks to the future under Brown's guidance, Gary Locke's legacy will remain a cherished part of the club's history. Meanwhile, his new role at Hearts is anticipated to usher in a period of renewed engagement and support for the Edinburgh club.

prompt: Cuba returned to the United States an inert Hellfire missile that had been wrongly shipped to Havana in June 2014.
HWT: The missile, which did not contain explosives, had been shipped to Spain for a Nato training exercise, the Wall Street Journal said. It was then taken to Germany and eventually to Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris for onward delivery to Florida. It was instead loaded on to an Air France flight to Havana. The incident could have led to a serious loss of military technology, officials told the Wall Street Journal. The whole affair has been embarrassing for the Americans, who have had to ask the Cubans if they could have their highly sensitive missile back, says the BBC's Will Grant in Havana. The missile arrived on a flight from Paris "by mistake or mishandling in the country of origin," said a Cuban Foreign Ministry statement. "Cuba acted with seriousness and transparency and co-operated to find a satisfactory solution to this issue," it added. The AGM 114 Hellfire is a laser-guided missile that can be deployed from an attack helicopter or an unmanned drone. US officials were worried that Cuba could share the advanced technology inside the missile with countries such as North Korea, China or Russia, sources close to the investigation told the Wall Street Journal. The US and Cuba, old Cold War enemies, restored diplomatic relations in July last year after more than 50 years. The two countries have been working to rebuild their economic and trade ties. An announcement is expected on Tuesday about the reinstatement of scores of commercial flights between US cities and Havana.
MGT:
In an unusual turn of events, Cuba has returned a U.S. Hellfire missile that was mistakenly shipped to Havana nearly nine years ago. The inert missile, which was used for training purposes and contained no explosive material, had been misrouted to the island nation in June 2014, raising concerns about sensitive military technology falling into unintended hands.

The incident reportedly occurred during a routine shipment of U.S. military equipment. The Hellfire missile, designed for precision strikes, was intended for a NATO training exercise in Europe but somehow ended up in Cuba. How the error occurred has not been publicly disclosed, but it immediately sparked alarm within U.S. defense and intelligence circles, as the weapon’s technology could have been studied or reverse-engineered.

Cuban officials, however, maintained possession of the inert missile without exploiting its technology, according to U.S. sources familiar with the matter. The Cuban government quietly returned the missile to the United States, resolving a sensitive issue that had lingered for years. The Pentagon has since implemented stricter oversight measures to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future.

The return of the missile is seen as a rare moment of cooperation between the two countries, which have had strained relations for decades. Analysts have noted that Cuba’s decision to return the missile intact may have been a gesture aimed at avoiding further political tension with Washington.

While the error has been resolved, the mishap remains a glaring reminder of the logistical challenges that can arise in the handling of advanced military equipment. The U.S. government has not disclosed the exact details of how the missile was recovered but has expressed relief that the matter has been concluded without further complications.

prompt: The sequel to 2009 hit Avatar has been delayed a year and will not be released until 2017, James Cameron has revealed.
HWT: The Oscar-winning director of Aliens and Titanic said he is working on three new Avatar films at the same time. The first film was supposed to be out in December 2016, but Cameron said writing the stories had become "very involved". "There's a layer of complexity in getting the story to work as a saga across three films," he explained. Cameron said the goal was to have the scripts for the three movies completed by the end of this month so that filming can begin. "We're writing three simultaneously and we've done that so that everything tracks throughout the three films," he told the Associated Press. "We're not just going to do one and then make up another one and another one after that. "And parallel with that, we're doing all the design. So we've designed all the creatures and the environments." Cameron said he thought it was important that each film linked forward to the next one in a satisfying way, but also came to a resolution that did not leave the audience hanging. The three films will be shot in New Zealand, where some of the original film was also made. Avatar is the highest-grossing film in history, with box office takings of almost $2.8 billion (Â£1.8 billion). Set in the 22nd Century on a distant planet inhabited by a humanoid race, the sci-fi epic went on to win three Oscars. Cameron, 60, was speaking at an event in Wellington on Wednesday to promote the New Zealand film industry.
MGT:
The highly anticipated sequel to James Cameron's 2009 blockbuster "Avatar" has been delayed, with its release now slated for 2017. The announcement was made by Cameron, who shared the news with fans eager to return to the lush, otherworldly landscapes of Pandora. Originally expected to hit theaters in 2016, the filmmaker explained that the delay was necessary to accommodate the ambitious scope of the project, which includes two additional sequels set to follow the second installment.

Cameron, renowned for his meticulous approach to storytelling and groundbreaking visuals, revealed that the complexity of developing three interconnected films simultaneously has posed unique challenges. "We’re writing all three at the same time, and we’ve done that so that everything interconnects across the trilogy," he said. "It’s a big job." The decision to release multiple sequels was driven by the immense success of the original "Avatar," which remains the highest-grossing film of all time, earning over $2.8 billion at the global box office.

Fans of the franchise have been eagerly awaiting the continuation of the story, which is expected to delve deeper into the mythology of Pandora and introduce new characters and locations. Cameron promised that the sequels will push the boundaries of filmmaking and visual effects, much like the original film did with its revolutionary use of 3D and motion capture technology.

While the delay may come as a disappointment to fans, many are optimistic that Cameron’s commitment to quality will ensure a cinematic experience worth the wait. As the filmmaker continues to refine his vision, audiences worldwide remain captivated by the promise of returning to the enchanting world of "Avatar" and exploring the next chapter of its epic tale.

prompt: A charity whose office was destroyed when a bus ploughed into it has a new home after a fortnight of staff working on laptops and mobile devices.
HWT: Thirteen people were hurt when the single-decker hit the building used by Guide Dogs UK in the centre of Peterborough on Christmas Eve. The charity has moved into an office in the Orton Southgate area of the city. Helen Sismore, community engagement manager, said: "We should be back in our repaired office by April." The bus went through the bay windows on the front of the charity's regional office on Broadway. Passengers had a variety of minor injuries but no-one was injured in the office where three people were in back rooms. Ms Sismore said: "We heard and felt the crash and it was horrific and the timing on Christmas Eve didn't help. "We've been working using laptops wherever we can find wi-fi, such as our homes, cafes and libraries. "No clients have suffered because we've been in telephone contact using our mobiles and we've had a lot of support from our volunteers and the local community." She said the repair of the rented Broadway offices was being covered by the landlord's insurance and they were renting the temporary office on Cully Court at the market rate.
MGT:
A local charity, left without a physical location after a bus unexpectedly crashed into its office, has found a new home after two weeks of resourceful adaptation by its dedicated staff. The incident, which occurred in the early hours of a Monday morning, left the office in ruins, displacing the charity's operations and leaving the team scrambling to maintain their essential services.

Despite the chaos, the charity's staff demonstrated remarkable resilience, quickly transitioning to a remote work setup. Armed with laptops and mobile devices, they continued to provide support and assistance to those in need, ensuring that the charity's mission remained uninterrupted. Staff members worked tirelessly from their homes, coffee shops, and other temporary locations, determined to overcome the unexpected setback.

After an intensive search for a suitable new location, the charity has successfully relocated to a new office space. This move marks a significant milestone in their recovery efforts, allowing the team to return to a more structured and efficient working environment. The new office, equipped with the necessary amenities, promises to enhance their ability to serve the community.

The charity's leadership expressed gratitude to the local community for their unwavering support during this challenging period. As they settle into their new headquarters, the team remains committed to their cause, even more motivated to make a positive impact.

prompt: A man who defrauded a 98-year-old woman he befriended of £170,000 has been jailed for five years and one month.
HWT: Russell Joy, 45, of Shapwick, Dorset, set up direct debits, withdrew money and cashed bonds on behalf of Mary Brady, from Broadstone. Bournemouth Crown Court heard Joy won the trust of the pensioner, who died earlier this month, when she hired him as her gardener in 2008. He was entrusted to withdraw money for her daily living expenses. In December 2014 he made the first of 107 withdrawals without her knowledge, totalling £32,100. The following November Ms Brady cashed five bonds in the sum of £230,000 and wrote Joy a cheque for £100,000. In March 2016, he received a further £20,000 cheque. He also withdrew money to buy a Land Rover car and set up a direct debit to pay his vehicle insurance. The offences came to light when the pensioner's relatives checked her finances while she was in hospital. In a statement, Ms Brady's family said they were "desperately sad" about the "ugly end" to her life. Det Insp Andy Dilworth said: "Russell Joy is nothing more than a callous fraudster. He befriended his victim over a period of many years and quickly earned her trust." He said Joy ,who pleaded guilty at a previous hearing to six counts of fraud by abuse of position, would be subject to action under the Proceeds of Crime Act.
MGT:
A man has been sentenced to five years and one month in prison after defrauding a 98-year-old woman of £170,000. The perpetrator, who formed a friendship with the elderly woman, exploited her trust over an extended period, siphoning off her life savings.

The court heard how the man manipulated the victim, who lived alone and relied on him for companionship and assistance. Under the guise of helping her manage her finances, he systematically drained her accounts, leaving her in a precarious financial situation. Prosecutors described his actions as "calculated and callous," highlighting the emotional and financial toll on the victim, who had placed her full confidence in him.

The fraud came to light when suspicious transactions were flagged by the woman's bank, prompting an investigation. Authorities uncovered a pattern of deceit, with the man using the stolen funds to finance a lavish lifestyle. During the trial, it was revealed that he had no intention of repaying the money and showed little remorse for his actions.

The judge condemned the man's betrayal, emphasizing the vulnerability of the victim and the breach of trust involved. In delivering the sentence, the judge stated that such predatory behavior deserved a significant punishment to serve as a deterrent.

The victim's family expressed relief that justice had been served but noted the lingering emotional impact on their loved one. Advocacy groups have called for stronger protections for the elderly to prevent similar cases of financial exploitation in the future.

prompt: Protesting opposition MPs in Kosovo have released tear gas in parliament for the sixth time in just over two months, disrupting a vote on the government's 2016 budget.
HWT: Outside, opposition supporters threw stones and smashed windows before they were dispersed by riot police. Protesters have been trying to disrupt parliament over an EU-brokered deal to improve relations with Serbia. Kosovo unilaterally declared its independence from Serbia in 2008. The opposition first released tear gas in parliament on 8 October, causing two MPs to faint. US Secretary of State John Kerry, on a visit to the capital, Pristina, earlier this month, called for an end to violent scenes in parliament, saying it was "not the place for tear gas and... not the place for intimidation". However, opposition MPs released gas canisters again in the parliamentary chamber on Monday, forcing a suspension of proceedings. A large group of plainclothes police officers donned gas masks as the chamber was cleared. One of the MPs who released the gas, Glauk Konjufca, said it was "a collective action by the opposition". "Others have done this too, and we will continue to do this in the future. Our breaching of the law is nothing compared to the damage that is being done by these agreements." The opposition is particularly opposed to a deal to give more autonomy to Kosovo's ethnic Serb minority, which they say could increase Serbia's influence. The vote on next year's €1.67bn (£1.1bn) budget resumed in a side room, with only MPs from the governing coalition present and was approved, Reuters news agency reported. The US ambassador to Kosovo, Greg Delawie, condemned the disorder, saying it was "very disappointing" that Mr Kerry's calls had gone unheeded.
MGT:
Opposition lawmakers in Kosovo have once again disrupted parliamentary proceedings by releasing tear gas inside the chamber. The incident marks the sixth time in just over two months that opposition MPs have resorted to such tactics, reflecting deep divisions over the government’s policies. The latest protest occurred during a session scheduled to vote on the 2016 budget, forcing lawmakers and staff to evacuate the chamber.

The opposition has been fiercely critical of recent agreements brokered by the government with Serbia and Montenegro. They argue that these deals undermine Kosovo's sovereignty and territorial integrity. Among the points of contention is a European Union-mediated agreement granting greater autonomy to Serb-majority municipalities within Kosovo. Opposition MPs contend that this move threatens to deepen ethnic divisions and weaken the country's governance.

Another issue fueling tensions is a border demarcation agreement with Montenegro, which the opposition claims cedes Kosovo territory. These concerns have led to repeated disruptions in parliament, with opposition leaders vowing to continue their protests until the government abandons the agreements. Tear gas has become their method of choice to block proceedings, drawing condemnation from government officials and international observers.

Prime Minister Isa Mustafa has criticized the opposition's tactics, describing them as harmful to democracy and the rule of law. He has urged lawmakers to engage in dialogue rather than resort to radical measures. However, opposition leaders remain defiant, accusing the government of betraying national interests.

The ongoing unrest has raised concerns about Kosovo's political stability, with international stakeholders calling for calm and constructive dialogue. As the country grapples with these internal divisions, the repeated use of tear gas in parliament underscores the intensity of the political deadlock and the challenges facing its young democracy.

prompt: Manufacturing sales from Northern Ireland were worth £13.3bn last year, the highest value on record.
HWT: External sales were up by 3.2% over the year, a rise of £415m. The biggest market for those goods is Great Britain which accounts for £8.1bn - just under half the total value. The Republic of Ireland is the next single biggest market at £1.3bn, followed by the rest of the EU at £1.2bn. Sales to all other parts of the world were £2.6bn. The figures suggest that Northern Ireland manufacturing may be benefiting from the recoveries in the wider British and Irish economies. Sales to GB were up by 6.2% while sales to the Republic of Ireland were up by 5.3%. However sales to other EU countries fell by 13%. The figures are produced by the  Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (NISRA). Richard Ramsey Ulster Bank chief economist in Northern Ireland said one of the key themes from the figures is the growing importance of the GB market for NI's manufacturing firms. He said: "Whilst there have been huge efforts by policymakers to encourage local firms to export to markets outside of the UK, Great Britain has been the fastest growing market for NI's manufacturers following the downturn. "Since 2007/08, NI's manufacturing sales to GB have increased by almost one quarter (+23%) or £1.5bn. "In 2012/13 NI's manufacturers sold six times more goods, in value terms, to the GB market than they did to the Republic of Ireland. "Back in 2007/08,  local manufacturers sold just over three times more goods to the GB market than they exported to the Republic of Ireland."
MGT:
Manufacturing sales in Northern Ireland reached an unprecedented milestone last year, with total sales valued at £13.3 billion—the highest figure ever recorded. The data highlights the resilience and growth within the region's manufacturing sector, which continues to play a pivotal role in driving economic activity and supporting local communities.

The record-breaking figure underscores the strength of Northern Ireland’s manufacturing industries amidst a challenging global economic environment. Despite pressures such as rising costs, supply chain disruptions, and broader uncertainties, the sector has demonstrated remarkable adaptability and innovation. Key contributors to the surge in sales include advanced engineering, food and beverage production, and pharmaceutical manufacturing, all of which have proven integral to sustaining the upward trajectory.

Experts believe that the sector’s success is deeply tied to Northern Ireland’s ability to leverage its skilled workforce, embrace cutting-edge technologies, and capitalize on export opportunities. International demand for high-quality goods produced in the region has continued to grow, further bolstering revenue streams. Local manufacturers have also benefited from strategic investments in infrastructure and government initiatives designed to foster growth and competitiveness.

The milestone is viewed as a significant achievement for Northern Ireland’s economy, providing a much-needed boost as other sectors face ongoing challenges. It also underscores the importance of continued support for manufacturing businesses to ensure they can sustain this momentum in the years ahead.

While the record-breaking sales figures are a cause for celebration, industry leaders have cautioned against complacency. They have emphasized the need for ongoing investment in skills development, innovation, and sustainability to safeguard the sector’s long-term success. As Northern Ireland’s manufacturing sector moves forward, its ability to adapt and thrive in a rapidly changing global landscape will remain crucial in shaping the region’s economic future.

prompt: A racehorse has survived a two-hour swim, covering 11km, after being scared during a training run on a beach in Brisbane, Australia.
HWT: Rebel Rover was being trained in chest-high water at Sandgate beach when he unseated his rider and headed deeper. The five-year-old gelding was picked up by the Brisbane Water Police and a marine rescue unit. "He was in about four metres of water and he was swimming quite freely," said Volunteer Marine Rescue's Glen Philip. Rebel Rover, with a track record of misdemeanours, has only recently made a comeback after being banned for misbehaving in the stalls. Trainer Brad Smith told ABC News that horses could swim, but did not normally do so very much. "Any other horse, 20 minutes would probably see them out, but this horse - he must have a pretty amazing lung capacity," he said. "The vet looked at him yesterday and again this morning and he's pretty well amazed with how he's coped with it all. Brisbane's Courier Mail reports he still had enough energy to head butt one of his support team, knocking them unconscious and putting them in hospital. Rebel Rover has won three of his 12 races.
MGT:
A racehorse in Brisbane, Australia, has made headlines after surviving an extraordinary two-hour swim, covering an astonishing 11 kilometers. The incident occurred during a routine training session on a beach, when the horse was startled and bolted into the water. Despite efforts to coax it back to shore, the animal continued swimming out to sea, leaving its handlers and onlookers deeply concerned.

The horse, whose name has not yet been disclosed, demonstrated remarkable stamina and resilience throughout the ordeal. Local authorities and rescue teams were alerted, with several boats dispatched to track the animal and ensure its safe return. Witnesses described the scene as both tense and surreal, as the horse powered through the waves, seemingly undeterred by the distance or the conditions.

After two hours in the water, the horse was safely guided back to shore, where veterinary teams were on hand to assess its condition. Miraculously, it emerged from the incident in good health, with no apparent injuries or signs of distress. The horse's trainers expressed relief and gratitude to the rescue teams, calling the animal’s survival a testament to its strength and endurance. The incident has left locals stunned and inspired, with many hailing the horse’s swim as an incredible feat.

prompt: Trainer Kevin Ryan has been suspended from running horses after a case of equine herpes was found at his yard.
HWT: Only one case has been discovered in Ryan's string but the yard near Thirsk has been placed under quarantine by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA). The nearby stables of trainers Bryan Smart and Michael Herrington have also been quarantined as a precaution. The BHA said they are working with Ryan and staff to ensure the correct disease control measures are in place. "The risk of the virus being transmitted in a controlled race-day environment is relatively small," said David Sykes, the BHA's director of equine health and welfare. "[But] it is in theory possible that horses from the yard in question may have been infectious some time before the disease was diagnosed. "For this reason we have taken measures to alert trainers, as well as racecourses and veterinary surgeons, to be vigilant to the clinical signs." The equine herpes virus can cause respiratory disease and abort foetuses, while a less common neurological form of the virus can cause co-ordination problems and paralysis, and is potentially fatal. The National Stud breeding site in Newmarket was closed last year following the discovery of the neurological herpes virus infection. Ryan won the French Derby and Irish Champion Stakes in 2014 with The Grey Gatsby and is a four-time winner of the Ayr Gold Cup, including the 2016 edition with Brando.
MGT:
Trainer Kevin Ryan has been temporarily suspended from running horses following the detection of a case of equine herpes at his yard. The announcement has sent ripples through the horse racing community, as precautions are being taken to prevent the spread of the highly infectious disease.

Equine herpes, a virus that can affect a horse’s respiratory and neurological systems, poses significant risks to both the health of the animals and the broader racing industry. Infected horses often require extensive care, and outbreaks can lead to stringent biosecurity measures, including quarantine protocols. The precise number of horses affected at Ryan’s yard has not been disclosed, but authorities have acted swiftly to mitigate the potential for wider transmission.

Ryan’s stable, known for producing numerous top-performing racehorses, has been placed under strict quarantine measures. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) is closely monitoring the situation and has confirmed that no horses from Ryan’s yard will be permitted to race until veterinary experts deem it safe to resume operations. Other trainers and yards have been advised to remain vigilant for any signs of the virus among their own horses.

This suspension marks a challenging period for Ryan, a highly respected figure in the sport. Racing schedules may also face disruptions as the industry grapples with the implications of the outbreak. For now, the focus remains on ensuring the health and safety of the horses, while efforts continue to contain the situation and prevent further spread of the virus.

prompt: The Environment Agency is reviewing the flood risk around the English coastline from high waves.
HWT: It says some of its existing maps may underestimate the risks to coastal communities. It is updating its National Flood Risk Assessment which informs members of the public and local authorities about the likelihood of flooding. The Environment Agency grades coastal areas at risk of flooding from very low to high. Environment Agency flood risks: High: Greater than one in 30 chance in any given year Medium: One in 30 to one in 200 chance in any given year Low: One in 200 to one in 1000 chance in any given year Very low: Less than one in 1,000 chance in any given year Last winter massive storms hit the South West coast with waves up to 15m (50ft) high, destroying part of the main railway line out of the region at Dawlish. Marcus Salmon, planning liaison technical specialist with the agency, said: "The storms have definitely reflected areas where our maps are not as representative as they can be. "That is something that we are working to address as quickly as possible. "Last winter's storms showed the susceptibility of our coastal communities and infrastructure to flooding and erosion. "The challenges presented by flooding and coastal erosion are expected to become more acute as a result of climate change, due to a combination of sea level rise, increased storminess and increased wave heights. "So as to better understand the risks we are updating the National Flood Risk Assessment to take account of wave, wind and storm surge which are underrepresented in our current mapping."
MGT:
In response to growing concerns about the impact of high waves and rising sea levels, the Environment Agency has initiated a comprehensive review of flood risks around the English coastline. This move comes as climate change continues to pose significant threats to coastal regions, with predictions of more frequent and severe weather events.

The review aims to assess the vulnerability of various coastal areas to flooding, considering factors such as wave height, tidal patterns, and existing flood defenses. The Environment Agency plans to use advanced modeling techniques and historical data to identify regions most at risk and recommend necessary improvements to infrastructure.

Flooding has long been a concern for communities along the English coast, with many areas experiencing devastating impacts in recent years. The agency's decision to review flood risks is part of a broader strategy to enhance resilience against climate-related challenges. By understanding the dynamics of high waves and their potential for causing coastal flooding, the agency hopes to develop targeted interventions that can protect homes, businesses, and natural habitats.

The review process will involve collaboration with local authorities, environmental experts, and community leaders to ensure a comprehensive approach. Public consultations are also expected to take place, allowing residents to voice their concerns and contribute to the development of effective flood management strategies.

As the Environment Agency embarks on this critical task, there is a growing recognition of the need for proactive measures to safeguard coastal communities. The review is not only a response to immediate threats but also a step towards long-term planning and adaptation to the challenges posed by climate change.

Ultimately, the findings of the review will inform policy decisions, guiding investments in flood defenses and shaping future efforts to protect the English coastline from the increasing risks associated with high waves.

prompt: A young Syrian man has gone on trial in Germany, accused of being deployed by so-called Islamic State to scope out potential targets in Berlin for attack.
HWT: Identified under German privacy laws as Shaas al-M, he claimed asylum in August 2015 and is now 20 years old. Federal prosecutors say before that he fought with the Islamist militants for two years in his home country. He is being tried by a special security court in Berlin, but reports suggest he refused to testify. He has been in custody since his arrest on 22 March. Shaas al-M's trial comes two weeks after Anis Amri ploughed a truck into a Christmas market in Berlin, killing 12 people. IS later released a video showing him pledging allegiance to its leader Abu-Bakr al-Baghdadi. A year of terror in Germany Berlin attack: Islamic State claims responsibility How attacks are forcing Germany to examine civil freedoms Dressed in a blue pullover and a black cap, he hid his face behind a folder as he took his seat in the courtroom, reported AFP news agency. Officers armed with machine guns were stationed outside the court. Shaas al-M faces charges of being a member of a foreign terrorist organisation, which carries up to 10 years in jail, and violating laws governing military weapons. In a previous statement (in German), the court detailed allegations of Shaas al-M's involvement in IS operations in Syria, including participating in the siege of the airport at Deir al-Zour, handling a Kalashnikov gun and helping supply fighters with food. Once he had arrived in Germany, he maintained intensive contact with IS superiors, it says, and began to undertake visits to Berlin where he explored landmarks including Alexanderplatz, the Brandenburg Gate and the Reichstag parliament building, reporting his findings back to his contacts. He is also accused of arranging for at least one person to travel to Syria to fight, and offering his services to assist would-be attackers travelling to Germany. The court has scheduled some 25 hearings to run until April.
MGT:
A young Syrian man has appeared in court in Germany, facing charges of collaborating with the so-called Islamic State (IS) to plan potential attacks in Berlin. The trial, which began this week, has drawn significant attention as authorities continue to grapple with the ongoing threat posed by extremist groups across Europe.

Prosecutors allege that the man, whose identity has not been disclosed under German privacy laws, was deployed by IS to survey possible targets for violent attacks in the German capital. According to the charges, the defendant was instructed to gather information about high-profile locations and events that could cause maximum disruption and casualties.

The young man reportedly arrived in Germany as a refugee in 2015 during the height of the Syrian civil war and the subsequent migration crisis. Authorities claim that he later became involved with IS, which tasked him with reconnaissance missions in Berlin. The prosecution argues that his actions formed part of a broader strategy by the extremist group to expand its reach into Europe and carry out attacks in Western countries.

During the trial's opening session, the court heard details of the defendant’s alleged communications with IS operatives. prompt: An e-book at the centre of a row over who can use the term "space marine" is back on sale on the Amazon website.

Such "providers usually don't have the resources and/or the inclination to investigate trademark infringement claims", it said. Many simply removed the disputed content immediately to stay "neutral" and avoid trouble, said the EFF, but that made it hard for those on the end of trademark claims to mount a challenge. The online chatter also prompted Games Workshop to put a statement about the row on its Facebook page, in which it said it had "no choice" but to act in cases where its trademarks in a commercially available product were being used without its consent. Despite this, it said, it had never claimed to have rights over the ways in which the terms "warhammer" or "space marine" were used in day-to-day speech. This everyday use also covered a "body of prose", it added. "Trademarks as opposed to use of a word in prose or everyday language are two very different things," it said. "Games Workshop is always vigilant in protecting the former, but never makes any claim to owning the latter."

prompt: The 70th anniversary of the pioneering Colossus computer is being celebrated at Bletchley Park.

Now widely recognised as the first electronic computer, Colossus was kept a secret for 30 years because of the sensitive work it did during World War Two to crack German codes. The work of the Colossus machines to decipher messages scrambled using the Lorenz enciphering machine that passed between the Wehrmacht's commanders is widely thought to have shortened the war and saved countless lives. Colossus was created by Post Office engineer Tommy Flowers, and his first prototype was built out of parts from telephone exchanges including 1,600 valves. Later versions used even more valves and by the end of the war 10 of the machines were in use in the UK. The celebrations will bring together some of the women who kept the different machines running as well as some of the engineers who built and maintained them. During wartime, about 550 people worked in the Bletchley Park unit that ran Colossus. Also attending will be some of the children of the machine's creators and operators. Most of the machines were broken up and the plans destroyed after the war in an attempt to keep the work secret and to conceal the fact Britain was still using two of the machines to read Soviet messages. "The achievements of those who worked at Bletchley Park are humbling," said Tim Reynolds, chair of TNMOC. "This day is in honour of all the men and women who worked on breaking the Lorenz cipher."
